n Steps - The processes at Pasadena Performance Products Plant have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  Safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances at the facility are in place to help prevent potential accidental scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human error.  

E.	Five-year Accident History 
The Pasadena Performance Products Plant is a new facility and has not had any accidental release as provided in 40 CFR §68.42 that reached beyond the property line or resulted in deaths on site, injuries or significant property damage on site, or any offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage or environmental damage since it started operations. 

F.	Emergency Response Program Information 
The Pasadena Performance Products Plant maintains a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP), which aims to protect employees, public health, and the environment (in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38, 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR 68).  The ERP defines the steps the facility and each employee should take during an accidental release of a regulated substance, natural disasters, and terrorist threats.  The plan includes both evacuation and protective action procedures for employees not directly involved in the response, and actions to be taken by employees responsible for responding to and mitigating the release. 
The ERP addresses all aspects of emergency response including notifying facility personnel, emergency response personnel, Harris County EMA/EMS, as well as Volunteer Fire Departments.  
All employees are trained in the applicable emergency response procedures. The most recent review of the ERP was done on February 4, 2023.

Employee Participation  NWEP believes that PSM and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.

Hot Work Permit - Hot work permits for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process will be issued by facility safety leaders.  The permit shall document that the fire prevention and protection requirements have been implemented prior to beginning the hot work operations; it shall indicate the date(s) authorized for hot work; and identify the object on which hot work is to be performed.  The permit will be kept on file until completion of the hot work operations.

Contractors - NWEP hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Before any contractors are allowed to work on the Pasadena Performance Products Plant, they undergo an orientation conducted by the PSM team.  During this orientation contractors are made aware of the known potential hazards related the contractor's work, the hazards of regulated substances, the safe work procedures insisted on by NWEP, and familiarized with the Hot Work Permit Policy and the Lock Out/Tag Out Procedures used at the Pasadena Performance Products Plant.  Contractors are informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur, and this information includes evacuation routes and assembly points.  NWEP will document that the contractor has received and understands the training.

Management of Change - Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  These procedures are updated as needed.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews - Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes will be conducted as a regular practice at the Pasadena Performance Products Plant.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications, and safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits - Regularly scheduled audits will be conducted to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  These audits will be carried out by at least one person knowledgeable in the process and conducted at least once every three years.  Audit findings will be documented in a report and corrective actions required from the audits will be undertaken in a safe and prompt manner and documented.

Incident Investigation - Any incident that results in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance will be promptly investigated.  An incident investigation will be initiated as promptly as possible, and will involve at least one person knowledgeable of the process involved. D.	General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:
The facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements, which are set out under 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68 of the EPA. The Pasadena Performance Products Plant is a PSM-covered facility and, as such, it has a viable process safety program. Workers and their representatives are consulted and have access to information regarding all PSM elements. Complete and accurate information on the process technology, process equipment, and hazardous characteristics and physical properties of all chemicals and intermediates for all covered processes is maintained. 

Process Safety Information  Pasadena Performance Products maintains a detailed record of process safety information that describes the hazards of regulated substances, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. Much of this information was compiled during the preparation of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA). Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs).

Process Hazard Analysis - The facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The HAZOP method is used to perform these evaluations. The studies were undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and will be revalidated at regular intervals of no more than 5 years. All findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

C.	The Worst-Case Release Scenarios and the Alternative Release Scenarios
a.	Worst Case Scenario:
EPA assumes the worst-case scenario to be a vapor cloud explosion and the RMP submittal must include this information.  For the Pasadena Plant, it was assumed that the single pressure vessel with the largest amount of flammable mixture (Isobutane Storage Sphere V-3301) had a catastrophic failure resulting in a vapor cloud explosion (VCE).  ALOHA (Version 5.4.7), an EPA-sponsored software tool, was used to calculate the distances to 1 psi of overpressure endpoint.  As described in the EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis, the worst-case scenario was carried out based on a release of isobutane.  Meteorological conditions for the worst-case scenario are defined in 40 CFR §68.22(b) as atmospheric stability class F (stable atmosphere) and wind speed of 1.5 m/s (3.4 mi/h).  The scenario involved a release of 705 lbs/min of isobutane for a 1-hour duration for a total release of 42,215 lbs.
b.	Alternative Case scenarios:
An alternative case scenario considered a loading hose failure on the Butane Truck loading rack resulting in a vapor cloud fire. Butane was selected as the predominant regulated component of the mixture, as it resulted in a greater distance to the lower flammable limit (LFL) endpoint.  ALOHA was used to predict a distance of 0.12 miles to the LFL endpoint, with a wind speed of 3 m/s and a stability class D with ambient air temperature (77°F). Next Wave Energy Partners, LLC (NWEP) owns and operates an alkylate production plant located in Harris County, Texas.
A.	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:
It is NWEPs policy to adhere to all Federal and State rules and regulations.  The Pasadena Performance Products Plant has established a commitment to worker and public safety as well as the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the facility. It is NWEP's policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If a release does occur, regular personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release. Also, NWEP has coordinated response activities with the Harris County EMA and local Fire and Rescue Departments.

B.	The stationary source and regulated substances handled:
The Pasadena Performance Products Plant is an alkylate production plant. The facility is located in an industrial area of Harris County in Pasadena, Texas. 
The facility includes a two phase process consisting of a dimerization process and an alkylation process to convert ethylene to alkylate, a gasoline additive.  The capacity of the facility is 28,000 barrels/day of alkylate.  Raw materials and a catalyst will be fed into a dimerization process where the dimerization of ethylene to butenes occurs in a liquid phase reactor loop.  The heavy and light ends are removed and stored while the butene is sent to the alkylation phase.  Residue gas from this phase will be sent to a thermal oxidation device.
In the alkylation phase, the butenes, isobutane and a sulfuric acid catalyst are reacted to form alkylate.  The alkylate product is a mixture of gasoline boiling range hydrocarbons that can be blended with the gasoline pool to increase the gasoline octane and reduce the vapor pressure.
